awd_titl_txt: Construction of Finite Elements Using Generalized Barycentric Coordinates and Its Application for Numerical  Solution of Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Continuous and smooth functions piecewisely defined over a domain which is a union of polygons or polyhedrons will be studied. These functions are called polygonal splines. Traditionally, functions defined on a domain consisting of triangles or tetrahedra were studied and used for many applications such as scattered data interpolation or fitting and numerical solution of partial differential equations. These traditional functions called finite elements or multivariate splines have been playing a significant and successful role in many applied problems in physics, chemistry, engineering, and biological studies. Polygonal splines defined on polygons instead of triangles can extend our ability to handle applied problems over complicated domains more effectively.  For example, polygonal splines over a union of irregular cubes will be more efficient than trivariate splines or finite elements since each cube has to be split into at least 5 tetrahedra in order to define finite element or trivariate spline functions over the cube. There are several fundamental properties one must understand in order to use them well for applications. For example, how many basis functions of polygonal splines over a collection of polygons are there? Another problem is how well polygonal splines can approximate arbitrary functions. 

The finite element method is the fundamental tool for numerical solution of partial differential equations (PDE) which finds extensive applications in all applied sciences. The PI will develop a new approach to construct serendipity finite elements using generalized barycentric coordinates over polygons or polyhedrons. One of the advantages of serendipity elements is to reduce the number of elements used for the numerical solution of PDE so that the computation will be more efficient. Polygonal splines developed in this project can be constructed over any irregular cubes. The PI will generalize some of the existing ideas to construct serendipity finite elements over a 3D convex polyhedron, e.g. irregular cube with six 2D quadrilaterals as its boundary faces as well as other more general convex polyhedra in the 3D setting. The PI will implement these serendipity finite elements for some linear and nonlinear PDEs in the 3D setting. Furthermore, the PI will construct differentiable high order serendipity elements over convex polygons in 2D and 3D which will be useful for higher order PDEs.

por.por_cntn:
Traditional spline functions are piecewise polynomial functions defined over a triangulation of a polygonal domain of interest.  Building blocks of these spline funcitons are barycentric coordinates.  It is interesting to construct spline functions over a collection of polygons of various number of sides which is more general than triangles. Generalized barycentric coordinates over polygons are the building blocks of splines over a polygonal partition.  Continuous polygonal splines based on generalized barycentric coordinates are constructed by the PI and his collaborators for any degrees over a partition of any number of polygons of any number of sides. These splines are used for numerical solution of Poisson equations and more general elliptic partial differential equations. Numerical experiments show that they work very well. These results were published in SIAM Journal of Numerical Analysis in 2016 and in a conference proceeding.  Hence, one of the goals of this NSF project is achieved. Another goal of the project is to construct smooth polygonal splines.  It turns out the task is extremely difficult. One of the PI's Ph.D. students James Lanterman devotes his dissertation on this topic and only achieves some partial results.  He is able to use generalized barycentric coordinates (GBC) of degree 5 to construct continuously differentiable splines over a collection of parallelograms. This part of results is submitted for publication.  For a partition of general quadrilaterals, he is able to use GBC of degree 7 to have C1 smooth splines. See Figures attached. These results are contained in his Ph.D. dissertation and will be written in a paper version later. Dr. Lanterman graduated on May, 2018 and found his job in a company working on research using his computational skills. In addition, the PI is looking for other methods to do the construction.  These results are still under preparation. The PI will continue working on this research problem.The third goal of the proposaed study is to extend the construction from the 2D to 3D and beyond. The PI have done the extension from 2D to 3D of the continuous splines in theory. However, the implementation of these splines for numerical solution of partial differential equations is not completed due to the intensive computation in the 3D setting,  automaticaly 3D partition of polyhedra  as well as quadrature formulas.

The intellectual merit of the proposed study is to have shown that construction of continous GBC elements of any order can be done and can be used for numerical solution of Poisson equations as well as other second order PDE.

The broader of impacts: the PI has released his MATLAB codes for polygonal elements of order 2 on-line at his webpage which has been downloaded several times.  In addition, one researcher from a National Lab. has requested and got the code for polygonal elements of order 3 from the PI. Three Ph.D. have been graduated under the PI supervision during the grant peorid.  Three more Ph.D. students will be graduated in the next two years.
